column1: The City of Sydney is the local government area covering the Sydney central business district and surrounding inner city suburbs of the greater metropolitan area of Sydney
column3: Australia. Established by Act of Parliament in 1842
column4: the City of Sydney is the oldest
column6: local government authority in New South Wales
column8: with only the City of Adelaide being older by two years.

column5: the City of Sydney has long been a source of political interest and intrigue. As a result of this
column7: constitution and legal basis of the council has changed many times throughout its history
column8: often to suit the governing party of the State of New South Wales. The City of Sydney is currently governed under the City of Sydney Act
column10: which defines and limits the powers
column12: constitution and boundaries of the council area. On 6 February 2004
column13: the former local government area of the City of South Sydney
column14: which itself had been created in 1989 from areas formerly part of the City of Sydney (including Alexandria
column18: was formally merged into the City of Sydney and the current city boundaries date from this merger.

column1: The leader of the City of Sydney is known as the Lord Mayor of Sydney
column2: currently held since 27 March 2004 by Clover Moore
column3: who also served concurrently as the state Member of Parliament for Sydney and Bligh from 1988 to 2012.

The name Sydney comes from "Sydney Cove" which is where the English Governor (later Admiral) Arthur Phillip established the first settlement
column2: after arriving with the First Fleet.  On 26 January 1788
column3: he named it after Thomas Townshend
column5: who was the home secretary at the time

column1: The "City of Sydney" was established on 20 July 1842 by the Corporation Act which encompasses present-day Woolloomooloo
column4: an area of 11.65 km². There were six wards established by boundary posts. These wards were: Gipps
column8: Cook and Phillip. A boundary post still exists in front of Sydney Square.

column1: The boundaries of the City of Sydney have changed fairly regularly since 1900. The bankrupt Municipality of Camperdown was merged with the city in 1909. As a result of the Local Government (Areas) Act 1948
column9: and Paddington were added to the City. In 1968 the boundaries were changed and many of these suburbs moved to be part of a new municipality of South Sydney. South Sydney was brought back into the city in 1982
column10: but became separate again under the City of Sydney Act of 1988 and then became smaller than its original size at 6.19 km². It grew again in February 2004 with the merger of the two council areas
column11: and now has a population of approximately 170

column1: These changes in boundaries have often resulted in control of the council by the governing party in the Parliament of New South Wales at the time; the Labor Party often sought to have traditional working-class suburbs like Redfern
column3: Alexandria and Waterloo included in the council area
column4: and the Liberal Party and its predecessors often desired a smaller council area focused on inner-Sydney or a limited/broader voting franchise. A 1987 re-organisation initiated by a Labor state government and completed in 1989 under a Liberal Coalition government saw the City of Sydney split again
column5: with southern suburbs forming the City of South Sydney
column6: a moved that advantaged the government of the day
column7: as the southern suburbs now in South Sydney Council had traditionally voted Labor.In 2004
column8: the Labor state Government undid this change
column9: again merging the councils of the City of Sydney and the South Sydney Council. Critics claimed that this was performed with the intention of creating a "super-council" which would be under the control of Labor
column10: which also controlled the NSW Government. Subsequent to this merger
column11: an election took place on 27 March 2004 which resulted in the independent candidate Clover Moore defeating the high-profile Labor candidate
column12: former federal minister Michael Lee and winning the position of Lord Mayor.

column3: 374 people in the Sydney local government area
column4: of these 51.8% were male and 48.2% were female. Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people made up 1.2% of the population. The median age of people in the City of Sydney was 32 years. Children aged 0 – 14 years made up 6.7% of the population and people aged 65 years and over made up 8.2% of the population. Of people in the area aged 15 years and over
column5: 25.7% were married and 9.1% were either divorced or separated.Population growth in the City of Sydney between the 2006 Census and the 2011 Census was 4.57%; with a significant increase of 22.93% between 2011 and 2016. When compared with total population growth of Australia of 8.81% between 2011 and 2016
column6: population growth in the Sydney local government area was almost triple the national average. The median weekly income for residents within the City of Sydney was just under 1.5 times the national average.The proportion of dwellings in the City of Sydney that are apartments or units is 77.1%
column7: which is substantially different from the Australian average of 13.1%. The proportion of residents in the Sydney local government area that claimed Australian ancestry was approximately one-quarter the national average.

column1: ^a  1996 Census figures refer to the City of Sydney prior to its merger with the City of South Sydney.
^b  2001 Census data comprise the sum of the former South Sydney and the former Sydney local government areas.
Sydney City Council is composed of ten Councillors
column3: for a fixed four-year term of office. The Lord Mayor is directly elected while the nine other Councillors are elected proportionally. The Deputy Lord Mayor is elected annually by the councillors. The most recent election was held on 10 September 2016

column1: The City of Sydney has adopted various policies to reduce the council's climate impact
column2: including strategies implemented since the 2000s to reduce car pollution by investing in mass and public transit and introducing a fleet of 10 new Nissan LEAF electric cars
column3: the largest order of the vehicle in Australia. The council has also invested in bicycle infrastructure
column4: and cycling trips have increased by 113% across Sydney's inner-city since March 2010
column6: 000 bikes passing through top peak-hour intersections on an average weekday.The City of Sydney became the first council in Australia to achieve formal certification as carbon-neutral in 2008. The city has reduced its 2007 carbon emissions by 6% and since 2006 has reduced carbon emissions from city buildings by up to 20%. In 2008
column7: the council adopted the Sustainable Sydney 2030 programme
column9: such as a comprehensive plan to reduce energy in homes and offices within Sydney by 30%. In the commercial space
column10: reductions in energy consumption have decreased energy bills by $30 million a year in more than half of office spaces
column11: and solar panels have been installed on many CBD buildings in an effort to minimise carbon pollution by around 3
column12: 000 tonnes a year. Sydney has become a leader in the development of green office buildings and enforcing the requirement of all building proposals to be energy-efficient.
